title: The Revelation of Christ
shortSummary: Revelation Chapter 1 introduces the divine revelation given to Jesus Christ and communicated through the apostle John. It presents a majestic vision of Christ, emphasizing His eternal nature, authority, and His role as the faithful witness to the churches in Asia. This chapter sets the foundation for the prophetic messages and visions that follow.
timeline: c. AD 95 - During the reign of Emperor Domitian, John receives the Revelation on the island of Patmos

keyCharacters.name: John
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and servant of Christ who receives and records the vision of Revelation while exiled on Patmos.

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The faithful witness, firstborn from the dead, and ruler over the kings of the earth, who reveals the prophecy to John.

keyCharacters.name: The Seven Angels
keyCharacters.description: Heavenly messengers who deliver the revelation to John for the seven churches in Asia.

definitions.definition: Titles for Christ meaning the beginning and the end, signifying His eternal nature and sovereignty.
A symbolic reference to the fullness and perfection of the Holy Spirit before God's throne.
Symbols representing the seven churches to whom the messages of Revelation are addressed.
A sharp double-edged sword proceeding from Christ’s mouth, symbolizing the power and authority of His word.

outline.heading: Introduction to the Revelation and its Purpose
outline.description: The chapter opens by declaring the source and purpose of the revelation given to Jesus Christ to show His servants what must soon take place, blessing those who read, hear, and keep the prophecy.

outline.heading: Greeting to the Seven Churches
outline.description: John addresses the seven churches in Asia, invoking grace and peace from the eternal God and Jesus Christ, who is described with titles affirming His faithfulness, resurrection, and sovereign authority.

outline.heading: John’s Vision on Patmos
outline.description: John identifies himself as a brother in tribulation and recounts being in the Spirit on the Lord’s Day when he hears a commanding voice instructing him to write what he sees and send it to the seven churches.

outline.heading: The Vision of the Son of Man Among the Candlesticks
outline.description: John sees seven golden candlesticks representing the churches and one like the Son of Man in their midst, described with symbolic imagery highlighting His purity, authority, and divine power.

outline.heading: Christ’s Comfort and Authority
outline.description: Overwhelmed by the vision, John falls at Christ’s feet; Christ reassures him, declares His eternal life and authority over death and hell, and explains the mystery of the seven stars and candlesticks.

application: Approach Scripture with reverence and obedience, recognizing the blessing promised to those who read, hear, and keep God’s prophetic word.
Trust in the eternal sovereignty and faithfulness of Jesus Christ, especially in times of trial and uncertainty.
Recognize the church’s calling to be a light in the world, represented by the candlesticks, and remain faithful to Christ’s authority.
Find comfort and courage in Christ’s presence and power, knowing He holds the keys to death and hell and is alive forevermore.

keyVerses.text: I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending, saith the Lord, which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms Christ’s eternal nature and supreme authority over all creation.

keyVerses.text: And when I saw him, I fell at his feet as dead. And he laid his right hand upon me, saying unto me, Fear not; I am the first and the last: I am he that liveth, and was dead; and, behold, I am alive for evermore, Amen; and have the keys of hell and of death.
keyVerses.significance: These verses reveal Christ’s victory over death and His comforting presence to believers.

keyVerses.text: Write the things which thou hast seen, and the things which are, and the things which shall be hereafter;
keyVerses.significance: This command establishes the structure of the entire book and emphasizes the importance of faithful record-keeping of God’s revelation.
